Both the truck and railcar loading/loadout areas have been equipped with containment devices. The truck loadout area is concrete and designed to direct the flow of potential spills to drains under this area. The drains are then directed into the tank farm's secondary containment area. A catchment basin is also located immediately below the railcar loadout. A spill to the railcar loadout catchment basin also drains back to the tank farm secondary containment via underground piping. Spill response materials are available throughout the facility to deal with minor spillage, as necessary. Spills shall be cleaned and removed promptly by trained employees. 

Additional Information Specific to Anhydrous Ammonia

Unlike spills of many other liquid products, anhydrous ammonia will immediately evaporate at ambient temperature and pressure. It will not travel overland and into drainage systems at the plant. Therefore, traditional spill containment practices will not work in responding to the release. Facility employees are not trained as first responders for an anhydrous ammonia release and the local Fire Dept. (911) o

r emergency contractor should be contacted. To prevent exposure employees should:
A¿	Stay upwind of a spill or threatened release. Although ammonia vapors are lighter than air in some cases ammonia will hug the ground and drift. 
A¿	Ammonia has excellent warning properties which may allow escape before concentrations affect health. Many people can detect ammonia odor at 1 to 5 parts per million which is a hundred times less than what is immediately dangerous to life and health. 
A¿	Preplan your escape route prior to working near anhydrous ammonia. 
A¿	Carefully approach with the wind at your back or perpendicular to incident source. 
A¿	If ammonia vapors are drifting across a road, no vehicles should be permitted to drive into the cloud.
A¿	Shelter in place or evacuate those residences down wind depending upon the expected ammonia air concentrations.

Off-site Consequence Analysis Results:

The worst case scenario at the facility is the release of 102,600 pounds of anhydrous ammonia creating a toxic cloud.  The worst-case scenario is based on the release of all ammonia stored on site.  The worst case vapor cloud endpoint is approximately 5.6 miles from the center of the plant.  Public receptors are located within this 5.6 mile radius.  For denaturant the worst-case scenario at the facility is the release of 660,040 pounds of denaturant creating a vapor cloud explosion.  The worst-case scenario is based on a release from the entire denaturant tank and both final denatured ethanol storage tanks.  The worst case vapor cloud endpoint is approximately 0.7 miles from the center of the facility.  Public receptors are also located within the 0.7 mile radius.
  
Although Sterling Ethanol, LLC has numerous controls in place to prevent such a release and to manage potential consequences, no credit for administrative controls or passive mitigation measures were taken into account in evaluating this scenario.

Since Sterling Ethanol, LLC qualifies as a Program 3 du

e to the close proximity of public receptors, Program Safety Management has been completed for this facility.

Since the facility also qualifies as a Program 3, Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS) were required.  The ARS is the release of 541,000 pounds of denaturant creating a vapor cloud explosion, which are the contents from just the denaturant tank.  The ARS endpoint is approximately 0.5 miles from the center of the facility.  The ARS for a toxic release of anhydrous ammonia is a leak for a 10-minute duration.  The ARS endpoint is approximately 1.3 miles from the center of the facility.  There are public receptors within both radiuses that would be affected by the alternative releases.

Five Year Accident History:

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or denaturant in the past five years that: Caused any death, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.

Planned changes to improve safety:

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the continuation of safe conditions. Updates to OSHA regulations, as well as other regulatory updates, are received by email and postal mail to be evaluated by staff regularly. There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia and denaturant safety recommendations for implementation at this time.

Emergency Response Program Information:

Sterling Ethanol, LLC has several safety programs in place at the facility that incorporate emergency response, including a Health and Safety Plan and Emergency Response Plan in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38. Sterling Ethanol, LLC has coordinated with local emergency responders and provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA). A Facility Res

ponse Plan (FRP) and Spill Prevention, Control, and Countermeasure (SPCC) Plan were also prepared and implemented for the denaturant and final product storage in accordance with applicable regulatory standards and timeframes. RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Sterling Ethanol, LLC (Facility ID: 100000193266)

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances:

The Sterling Ethanol, LLC Ethanol Plant is located near Sterling, Logan County, Colorado.

The facility operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for the purpose of manufacturing fuel grade ethanol from dry-milled corn.  The primary activity at the facility is the production of fuel grade ethanol.  Processes involved in this activity include a) the receiving and milling of corn, b) liquefaction of the milled corn to produce mash, c) fermentation of the mash to produce beer, d) distillation of the beer to produce ethanol, and e) denaturing of the ethanol.  

The regulated substances under the RMP program are Anhydrous Ammonia and Denaturant (natural gasoline) which are considered a toxic substance and flammable mixture, respectively. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and used in the liquefaction process to adjust pH levels. The maximum quantity of ammonia stored would be 102,420 pounds in one storage tank. Denaturant is added to the ethanol at the end of the process so the final product is not fit for human consumption.

Sterling Ethanol, LLC has determined that the radius of impact from a worst-case release would be approximately 5.6 miles; due to the amount of anhydrous ammonia stored on site.  The radius of impact for a worst-case denaturant release is approximately 0.7 miles.
   
Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies:

Sterling Ethanol, LLC is committed to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated in the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel as well as considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the facility.

Sterling Ethanol, LLC's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, plant personnel will respond

Medium Discharge and Worst Case Release Scenarios

A release is considered non-incidental if it has one or more of the following criteria: 

A¿	The released substance cannot be absorbed or otherwise controlled at the time of release by employees or other trained persons present;
A¿	The release is either outside facility buildings on a porous surface or inside and has the potential to reach pervious surfaces (i.e., soil), or storm water drainage;
A¿	The released material is more than 25 gallons;
A¿	The release may pose a threat to human health and the environment if the release is not immediately controlled.
